code: @Manual{,   title = {hercgeos: Analyze and Manipulate Spatial and Geometric Data from the US Census},   author = {Ben Taft},   year = {2023},   note = {https://higherx4racine.github.io/hercgeos/, https://github.com/higherX4Racine/hercgeos}, }

what: Analyze and Manipulate Spatial and Geometric Data from the US Census
title: Analyze and Manipulate Spatial and Geometric Data from the US Census
text: goal hercgeos make little easier efficient work spatial data US Census related sources.

title: Analyze and Manipulate Spatial and Geometric Data from the US Census
text: can install development version hercgeos GitHub :

title: Analyze and Manipulate Spatial and Geometric Data from the US Census
text: fresh---servers TIGER/Line® shapefiles EXECRABLE column names. hercgeos helps . Original column names Repaired column names also nice presets mapping
code: library(hercgeos) NASHVILLE_NH |>     purrr::discard_at("historic_district") |>     purrr::map(names) |>     tibble::enframe(name = "Layer", value = "Names") |>     knitr::kable(caption = "Original column names") NASHVILLE_NH |>     purrr::discard_at("historic_district") |>     purrr::map(fix_old_year_suffixes) |>     purrr::map(names) |>     tibble::enframe(name = "Layer", value = "Names") |>     knitr::kable(caption = "Repaired column names") ggplot2::ggplot() +     geom_terrain(         NASHVILLE_NH$blocks |>             fix_old_year_suffixes() |>             fix_latlong_to_numeric() |>             transform_tiger_to_utm() |>             dplyr::mutate(                 Terrain = terrain_factor(.data$UR,                                          .data$AWATER,                                          .data$ALAND)             )     ) +     ggplot2::geom_sf(         data = NASHVILLE_NH$tracts |>             fix_latlong_to_numeric() |>             transform_tiger_to_utm(),         fill = NA,         color = "#ff2222",         linewidth = ggplot2::rel(2)     ) +     ggplot2::theme_minimal()

what: Two 2020 Census tracts from the northern part of Nashua, NH. — NASHVILLE_NH
title: Two 2020 Census tracts from the northern part of Nashua, NH. — NASHVILLE_NH
text: northern part city Nashua, NH briefly seceded becoming town, Nashville. tracts roughly area. set simple features created filtering, otherwise changing, file every 2020 Census tract New Hampshire.

title: Two 2020 Census tracts from the northern part of Nashua, NH. — NASHVILLE_NH
Two 2020 Census tracts from the northern part of Nashua, NH. — NASHVILLE_NH
text: NASHVILLE_NH list three tibbles simple features blocks : census blocks within tracts. tracts : Tracts "33011010400" "33011010500" 2020 US Census. historic_district : registered national historic place Nashville, NH. blocks tracts, columns verbatim find freshly-downloaded TIGER/Line shapefiles. historic_district, columns "RESNAME", "SRC_DAT", "NR_PROP"

title: Two 2020 Census tracts from the northern part of Nashua, NH. — NASHVILLE_NH
text: National Register Historic Places' database shapefiles: https://irma.nps.gov/DataStore/Reference/Profile/2210280 US Censu Bureau's TIGER/Line shapefile database: https://www.census.gov/cgi-bin/geo/shapefiles/index.php

what: Convert interpreted latitude and longitude from text to numbers — fix_latlong_to_numeric
title: Convert interpreted latitude and longitude from text to numbers — fix_latlong_to_numeric
text: census fields "INTPTLAT" "INTPTLON" contain "+" "-" characters. reason, sf::read_sf interprets character, numeric, columns. function rectifies .

title: Convert interpreted latitude and longitude from text to numbers — fix_latlong_to_numeric
Convert interpreted latitude and longitude from text to numbers — fix_latlong_to_numeric
text: .features tibble fields start "INTPT"

title: Convert interpreted latitude and longitude from text to numbers — fix_latlong_to_numeric
text: tibble, fields converted numbers

title: Convert interpreted latitude and longitude from text to numbers — fix_latlong_to_numeric
code: data.frame(   INTPTLAT = c("-4.4", "+3.3", "-2.2", "+1.1"),   INTPTLON = c(3, 1, 4, 1) ) |> fix_latlong_to_numeric() #>   INTPTLAT INTPTLON #> 1     -4.4        3 #> 2      3.3        1 #> 3     -2.2        4 #> 4      1.1        1

what: Coalesce NAME and NAMELSAD fields to fix blank NAME entries — fix_names_by_coalescing
title: Coalesce NAME and NAMELSAD fields to fix blank NAME entries — fix_names_by_coalescing
text: Census TIGER/Line shapefiles NAME NAMELSAD field, NAME one sometimes blank. NAMELSAD values often informative. especially true things like blocks tracts. function condenses NAME remove NAMELSAD. prefers values NAMELSAD, different. NAME NAMELSAD removed.

title: Coalesce NAME and NAMELSAD fields to fix blank NAME entries — fix_names_by_coalescing
Coalesce NAME and NAMELSAD fields to fix blank NAME entries — fix_names_by_coalescing
text: .features tibble NAME NAMELSAD features.

title: Coalesce NAME and NAMELSAD fields to fix blank NAME entries — fix_names_by_coalescing
text: tibble additional column, "Name," neither "NAME" "NAMELSAD"

title: Coalesce NAME and NAMELSAD fields to fix blank NAME entries — fix_names_by_coalescing
code: data.frame(   NAME = c("Townsville", "", NA),   NAMELSAD = c("The City of Townsville", "Metrograd", "Locationopolis") ) |> fix_names_by_coalescing() #>                     Name #> 1 The City of Townsville #> 2              Metrograd #> 3         Locationopolis

Filter one or more geometries by a reference geometry using a single

text: subset .target_geoms meets criteria represented .reference_geom .predicate

title:
Filter one or more geometries by a reference geometry using a single
geometric predicate. — geometry_filter
code: library(sf) #> Linking to GEOS 3.10.2, GDAL 3.4.1, PROJ 8.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE targets <- st_sf(label = letters[1:3],                  geometry = c(UNIT_PENTAGON + c(1, 1),                               UNIT_PENTAGON + c(2, 2),                               UNIT_PENTAGON + c(3, 3)),                  sf_column_name = "geometry") geometry_filter(targets, UNIT_PENTAGON, st_intersects, "label") #> [1] label #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)
